Award.AwardTitle: ABI Innovation: Beyond dN/dS: Population Genetics, Genome Structure, and Protein Structure
Award.AbstractNarration:
Full genome sequences, including the sequence for all protein-encoding genes, now exist for many different species. Within these sequences lie the molecular underpinnings of species differentiation. Presently it is not possible to systematically compare homologous genes from different species and predict which have changed function. New mechanistic models that describe the underlying population genetic, evolutionary, and biochemical processes and constraints on amino acid change between species will be developed and applied to genome comparisons, including to the divergence between humans and chimpanzees. Additionally, the project will provide educational opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students as well as postdoctoral training. Further, a popular video, interactive educational website, and poster-based museum exhibit on comparative genomics will be produced to explain the concepts of comparative genomic analysis to a popular science audience. The project involves collaboration with the American Museum of Natural History and researchers at University of Otago in New Zealand.

Current widely used approaches in comparative genomics simply look for a statistical excess of nucleotide changes that change the encoded amino acid, normalized by the expectation from synonymous nucleotide changes (the ratio of nonsynonymous to synonymous nucleotide substitution rates), but do not look at amino acid biochemistry or structural biology. They also do not consider genome structure (linkage) or population genetic considerations of the probability of fixation of an amino acid change. This research will develop approaches that explicitly consider the linkage of sites on chromosomes in a population genetic model and in different ways, also consider the biochemical and structural context of amino acid changes. The new models will be used initially in comparisons of the human and chimpanzee genome protein coding set and will subsequently be implemented in a phylogenetic context to enable comparison of gene families from multiple species. Potential downstream applications of this modeling approach that enables better mechanistic understanding of lineage-specific evolution include prediction of proteins or pathways where functions have changed. This can point to proteins and pathways that make a species unique as well as validating when model organisms are likely to be good models for particular molecular systems. Information related to this project will be available at http://sites.temple.edu/liberles/.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Computationally detecting the genes that have changed function under selective pressure between closely related species is one of the biggest challenges in comparative genomic analysis. Models that characterize the probability of introducing a mutation coupled to the probability that the mutation once introduced in a single individual, after time appears in all individuals of the species (goes to fixation) dependent upon the selective advantage (called mutation-selection models) have become more popular. This popularity stems from their relationship to the underlying biological process by which sequences evolve in populations.

For such models to better characterize the underlying biology, they need to be able to detect when the optimal amino acid sequence for a given function has shifted between species and this requires additional mathematical complexity to treat. Additionally, standard models assume that each mutation fixes independently. However, when the mutation rate is high or the number of individuals in the population is large, some mutations that are linked together on a chromosome in a gene fix together. When mutations fix jointly rather than independently, the assumption of independent fixation leads to incorrect measurement of the selective advantage of each mutation. We have generated modeling frameworks that enable identification of where the optimal amino acid sequence has shifted over time and that detect when the probability of two mutations fixing together is high.

Further, the number of individuals in a population affects both the probability of a new mutation being introduced to the population of a species as well as the probability of a mutation fixing (and fixing together vs. independently). As part of this grant, we have presented the case for the need to treat those characterizations of the population size differently.

Lastly, several videos were made as part of this project. One of the videos, made for the general public, was released on youtube (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=S3ietoB5qLE&t=17s) and is on display at the American Museum of Natural History. This video describes the role of a protein encoding gene in enabling vampire bats to feed on mammalian species and also presents a popular science introduction to comparative genomic data analysis to detect such links between gene evolution and species evolution.
